In every case, once your money is entirely negatively imaginary, you can withdraw money every compounding cycle until it's entirely negatively imaginary again. Put it in another savings account; you have effectively 100% APR on the magnitude of the account's value. Or, as others have suggested, simply borrow money! If it's continuously compounding, you can begin to withdraw the amount you borrowed after one year, every year.

But even if they don't let you do that, if you can put any amount of money into the account and wait til it's entirely negative imaginary, or negative imaginary plus a small real amount, you will be able to withdraw at least the magnitude of the principal every year. In the compounding-yearly example, after only six years, you are able to withdraw 8P every year after just 6 years, which is much better, in my opinion, than taking your 16P and running. After just two years of this, you could open a new account with the same interest rate (if they let you) and start that one at 16P, while still maintaining an account returning 8P every year.

Of course this is nonsense; no bank would ever have an account like this, but it is fun to think about!

Just improvised it, but there is a quaternion notation in terms of complex numbers. For real numbers α, β, γ, δ you get complex numbers ε = α + βi, ζ = γ + δi and a quaternion ε + ζj – with (1, i, j, k) the quaternion base and thus k = ij – so that:

ε + ζj
= α + βi + (γ + δi)j
= α + βi + γj + δij
= α + βi + γj + δk

Also the quaternions can be modelled as special 2x2 complex matrices of the form [[w, −z], [z*, w*]] with complex numbers w and z ("*" meaning conjugation). (Ebbinghaus et al.: "Numbers")

Another infiltration of the imaginary in our otherwise sane world. Read on!

Light is refracted (bent) when going from air to water. (Think of how your straw has a bend in it at the surface of your water glass.) The amount of this bend depends on the ratio of the speed of light in water (slower) compared to air (faster). The amount that light is slowed down by any media is called the index of refraction, n. For example: vacuum = 1, air = 1.0+, water = 1.33, glass = 1.5, diamond = 2.42. Sounds pretty generic, right? Just a simple number. Not so fast! Because of the imaginary terms in the quantum mechanical equation of a light wave, if you add a complex component to the index of refraction, it will act as an attenuation (absorbing) of the light in the medium. Now isn't THAT obvious? So don't be surprised when Grant asks you, "HEY! What if we add an imaginary component to the index of refraction?" You'll be ready.

You can go from complex numbers to quaternions by repeating (one of) the ways to go from real numbers to complex numbers. You can think of complex numbers as the extension of real numbers by an additional number i, where i^2 = -1. All complex numbers can be written as a+bi, where a, b are real. Any higher powers of i get reduced by i^2=-1. If you add a second number j, where j^2 = -1 and ij = -ji, then you can write all numbers in this new system as z+wj = (a+bi) + (c+di)j = a+bi + cj + dij. You can calculate that (ij)^2 = ijij = -ijji = ii = -1 (assuming multiplication is associative). Let's simplify this by saying k = ij. The value ijk = ijij = -1, so we have i^2 = j^2 = k^2 = ijk = -1, the definition of quaternions.

This example seems to support the legitimacy of the term "imaginary numbers", the historic term that you and others have described as misleading, because they are just as "real" as real numbers.
Even though it seems silly, a bank really could offer an annual interest rate of i, or some fractional multiplier of i, compounded annually.
But, the account could only be liquidated and closed when the account balance was entirely real (negative or positive) and thus offset by depositing or withdrawing a corresponding amount of real money.
At all other times, the account's "imaginary" balance would be mathematically valid as a ledger balance, even transferable to another account, but not representable or usable in the "real" world.
In this example, isn't "imaginary" a reasonable and informative adjective for the account balance?

You can think of it like this, 100 compounded every year at 12% is 112 at the end of the year. 100 compounded at 1% of every month is this:
1st month--100(1+.01)=101
2nd month--101(1+.01)=101.1
And so on and so on
So even though overall you compound 12% per year the average amount you compounded per year is greater than 100.

When expanding (1+x/n)^n, look at the x^k term, we are basically choosing x/n from k terms in the product and choosing 1 from other terms in the product, which means the coefficient is (n choose k)(1/n)^k = n! / (k!(n-k)!(n^k)).


As n approaches infinity, (n!/(n-k)!) = n(n-1)...(n-k+1) becomes same as (n^k) because n/(n-r) approaches 1 for any r between 0 and k-1. Therefore the coefficient would approach 1/k!.

If you consider the imaginary money credit and the real money debit, then the imaginary interest rate starts to make sense.  This SEEMS nonsensical, but it depends on what you and the bank can do with your money at any given time in the cycle.  When your money is real and positive, you can withdraw it and the bank cannot use it.  When your money is imaginary and positive, you can borrow against it (and pay interest to yourself).  When your money is real and negative, you have to pay back any borrowed imaginary funds and increase your real principle (that is, save more!).   When your money is imaginary and negative, the bank can borrow against your account and will pay you back in the same manner as you just paid yourself previously.  Finally, when the cycle is over you can withdraw your principle or let it continue on another cycle.  I'd take that deal.

If you wait pi/4 years again, then you'll have 70.71$ * sin(7*pi/4) + 70.71$ * i * cos(7*pi/4) = 50$ + 50i$. You take out the 50 dollars, and now you have already taken out at least 120$ after only 2pi years. Here's a sense in which quaternions arise from complex numbers in the same way that complex arise from reals. Let's represent 2x2 matrices as [a b; c d], where [a b] is the 1st row & [c d] the 2nd. Also, represent the conjugate of z as z*.

First, complex arithmetic is equivalent to that of 2x2 matrices of the form [a -b; b* a*] for real numbers a & b. (Here the *s are vacuous, but harmless.) Each such matrix can be decomposed as a•I + b•K, where I is the 2x2 identity matrix & K = [0 -1; 1 0]. Note that K² = -1•I, and that K as a linear transformation is a 90° rotation in R². (Thus we could have obtained the complex numbers as the algebra of scaled rotations in the plane, if only linear algebra had been developed before the theory of polynomials; nothing "imaginary" about it.)

Next, define complex numbers z = x+iy & w = u+iv, and create the matrix Q = [z -w; w* z*], by analogy with the previous matrix. Then Q = [x+iy -u-iv; u-iv x-iy], and can be decomposed as Q = x•I + y•J + u•K + v•L, where I & K are as before, J = [i 0; 0 -i] & L = [0 -i; -i 0]. Now we have matrix products J² = K² = L² = JKL = -1•I, which are the defining equations of the quaternions expressed in complex 2x2 matrix form. [qed]

Unfortunately, I think you've made a fundamental mistake in translating your word problem: you've discarded the real portion of the (interest) exponent.

If there is an account with an interest rate of x, simple compounded once after a period of time T, then at time T I have principal P * (1 + x) in the account. Alternatively, with continuous compounding, it's P * e^((1 + x) * T).

So with simple compounding, at time T, I have P + P*i dollars (not just P*i dollars).

With continuous compounding, it's P * e^((1 + i) * T) = P * e^(T + Ti). NOT P * e^(Ti), as shown ~37:35.

So the time-varying amount of the money in the account should be spiraling outward away from the origin, not walking around a circle.

As to whether you should deposit to such an account, assuming [1] you can afford to tie up your money for the length of time required to get a positive return, and [2] there is no penalty for maintaining negative real or imaginary dollars in the account, then YES. UNLESS you can get a loan with an imaginary interest rate and withdraw the positive real money (more than what was initially borrowed) after pi years. 😀

My working through of the challenge at 29:00:
Consider coefficient of x^3 in the expansion of (1 + x/n)^n. Since the x^3 terms arise from picking x/n for any three of the terms in the expansion and 1 for all the others, we get n choose 3 copies of x^3/n^3. Adding those together, the term is nC3*x^3/n^3, meaning the coefficient is nC3/n^3.
Now by the formula for nC3, we have nC3/n^3 = n! / (3! * (n-3)!) /n^3.
n!/(n-3)! is the same as n(n-1)(n-2), so it's a cubic polynomial. This means that we get:
(n^3 - 3n^2 + 2n) / n^3 * (1/3!)
For large values of n, all of the lower degree terms in the polynomial become negligible, and (n^3 - 3n^2 + 2n) / n^3 converges to n^3/n^3 = 1. So all that's left is the 1/3!, which is the coefficient of x^3 in the infinite series.
All of the same reasoning goes for the coefficient of x^k. The ratio n!/(n-k)! ends up simplifying to a polynomial with leading term n^k and a bunch of negligible lower terms. As n gets very large, this will cancel with the n^k term on the bottom, leaving us with a coefficient of 1/k!.

I think Euler's formula along with the property that exp(x+y)=exp(x)exp(y) comes off as very intuitive if we interpret calculating exp(x) as multiplying 1 by (1+h) approximately (x/h) times, and h tends to 0. This has the interpretation that we start at 1 at x=0, and earn a very small interest of 100h% in each successive time interval of h seconds, for x seconds. Hence, computing exp(x+y) is just like multiplying 1 by (1+h), approximately (x+y)/h times, which should be approximately the same as multiplying 1 by (1+h) x/h times and then multiplying the result by (1+h) y/h times (This suggests that exp(x+y)=exp(x)exp(y)). As h tends to zero, the approximations should turn to equalities (I guess?). To compute exp(ix), we multiply 1 by (1+ih), approximately x/h times. (1+ih) corresponds to an angle of arctan(h) which is approximately 'h' for radian 'h'. So we end up rotating by an angle 'x' after 'x/h' successive rotations of h radians.

I remember being really confused in high school when we first did that interest rate problem. I didn’t understand why dividing the rate when shortening the intervals was presented as the most logical thing, because we had already talked all the time about how it was exponential, not linear. What I saw you’d want the square root if you halved the interval, and the 12th root if it was 12 times as often. It annoyed me that they were shoving this linear reasoning peg into an exponential-shaped hole. And then that forces you into talking about getting interest “continuously,” which doesn’t make sense in this context. I definitely get interest in my bank account only every month. Like, I’d think about, say, you’re getting a certain rate every month, you could ask what is the effective rate each year. If it were 1% each month, then after a year, you’d have C*(1.01)^12= C*1.1268... so you’re getting 12.68% each year. I think that would give you a path to doing it the other way around. 12% per year means you’d multiply by (1.12)^(1/12)=1.0094888, so 0.9488% per month.

For example, this is the reason why, in pianos, to get the next key up, you multiply the frequency by 2^(1/12), so that once you’ve gone up a whole octave, it’s twice the frequency of the original note. You don’t make it so the differences are the same, you make it so the ratios are all the same.

Some matrices commute. When A and B are matrices, exp(A+B) = exp(A)exp(B) when AB = BA — when A and B commute. Thing is, the statement is true for real numbers and complex numbers as well. When ab = ba (when a&b commute), then exp(a+b) = exp(a)exp(b). Only for real/complex numbers, this is true for all possible pairs of numbers, which is why this property of exponents is always true for them. For matrices, this property is restricted to the specific case where AB = BA; when AB ≠ BA, the expression exp(A+B) = exp(A)exp(B) is not necessarily true.

This is a really interesting, informative and even incredibly useful vid. Why is it incredibly useful?
Because if a young person absorbs this lesson they are provided with the means to become independently wealthy within their lifetime with very little effort.

But I would like to draw your attention to an interesting anomaly I discovered later in life.
While the finance industry calculates interest in a mathematically correct manner for time periods of one year or greater, if the time period is less than one year they calculate interest with a fudge.
In the finance industry if the interest is calculated monthly they use a factor of the nominal annual rate divided by 12, and as you know these are not equivalent.
This puzzled me when I first discovered it, but I now understand the reason why.
When financiers first needed to calculate interest rates they had no electronic calculators. They had to calculate the numbers with pencil and paper. That is hundreds of years ago. And calculating interest paid on daily, using an annual rate was a chore. Electronic calculators and computer make these calculations in sub 1 second time frames.
But the finance industry retains the old methods even today.
I discovered this when I purchased a Hewlett Packard 12C, the finance calculator.
I thought that being a calculator it would calculate the interest mathematically correctly.
Well it doesn't. Surprise. It calculates it using the traditional method, in which the interest paid monthly is one twelfth of the annual rate.
So read your loan contract closely and determine the method by which the lender has agreed to pay your interest.
Needless to say, using the annual rate divided by 12 is to the lenders advantage because the amount paid is the same as one payment made annually. No surprise there.

well, at the end the question about the exponential identity for matrices is pretty easy.

exp(A)*exp(B)=exp(A+B)

if A and B are real (or even complex) numbers, the identity holds. in case of real and complex numbers addition and multiplication are also commutative. but for matrices only addition remains commutative, matrix multiplication breaks this symmetry. this non-commutativity is the reason that the above identity is not valid anymore. why? because the exponential of a matrix is also a matrix. so the left hand side of the identity above is a multiplication of two matrices meanwhile the right hand side contains an addition of two matrices (then the exponential of this sum). so one side of the equation is commutative, the other side of the equation is non-commutative. this is a clear sign that the equation does not hold in general. because exp(A+B)=exp(B+A), meanwhile exp(A)*exp(B)≠exp(B)*exp(A), so two terms should be equal and not equal at the same time. contradiction...
